segment.source: Create shaders and drawing primitives
segment.target: Create shaders and drawing primitives

segment.source: Here, we show you how to use HLSL source files to compile and create shaders that you can then use to draw primitives on the display.
segment.target: Here, we show you how to use HLSL source files to compile and create shaders that you can then use to draw primitives on the display.

segment.source: Create shaders and drawing primitives
segment.target: Create shaders and drawing primitives

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Here, we show you how to use HLSL source files to compile and create shaders that you can then use to draw primitives on the display.
segment.target: Here, we show you how to use HLSL source files to compile and create shaders that you can then use to draw primitives on the display.

segment.source: We create and draw a yellow triangle by using vertex and pixel shaders.
segment.target: We create and draw a yellow triangle by using vertex and pixel shaders.

segment.source: After we create the Direct3D device, the swap chain, and the render-target view, we read data from binary shader object files on the disk.
segment.target: After we create the Direct3D device, the swap chain, and the render-target view, we read data from binary shader object files on the disk.

segment.source: Objective: To create shaders and to draw primitives.
segment.target: Objective: To create shaders and to draw primitives.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: We assume that you are familiar with C++.
segment.target: We assume that you are familiar with C++.

segment.source: You also need basic experience with graphics programming concepts.
segment.target: You also need basic experience with graphics programming concepts.

segment.source: We also assume that you went through Quickstart: setting up DirectX resources and displaying an image.
segment.target: We also assume that you went through Quickstart: setting up DirectX resources and displaying an image.

segment.source: Time to complete: 20 minutes.
segment.target: Time to complete: 20 minutes.

segment.source: Instructions
segment.target: Instructions

segment.source: 1. Compiling HLSL source files
segment.target: 1. Compiling HLSL source files

segment.source: Microsoft Visual Studio uses the fxc.exe HLSL code compiler to compile the .hlsl source files (SimpleVertexShader.hlsl and SimplePixelShader.hlsl) into .cso binary shader object files (SimpleVertexShader.cso and SimplePixelShader.cso).
segment.target: Microsoft Visual Studio uses the fxc.exe HLSL code compiler to compile the .hlsl source files (SimpleVertexShader.hlsl and SimplePixelShader.hlsl) into .cso binary shader object files (SimpleVertexShader.cso and SimplePixelShader.cso).

segment.source: For more info about the HLSL code compiler, see Effect-Compiler Tool.
segment.target: For more info about the HLSL code compiler, see Effect-Compiler Tool.

segment.source: For more info about compiling shader code, see Compiling Shaders.
segment.target: For more info about compiling shader code, see Compiling Shaders.

segment.source: Here is the code in SimpleVertexShader.hlsl:
segment.target: Here is the code in SimpleVertexShader.hlsl:

segment.source: Here is the code in SimplePixelShader.hlsl:
segment.target: Here is the code in SimplePixelShader.hlsl:

segment.source: 2. Reading data from disk
segment.target: 2. Reading data from disk

segment.source: We use the DX::ReadDataAsync function from DirectXHelper.h in the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template to asynchronously read data from a file on the disk.
segment.target: We use the DX::ReadDataAsync function from DirectXHelper.h in the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template to asynchronously read data from a file on the disk.

segment.source: 3. Creating vertex and pixel shaders
segment.target: 3. Creating vertex and pixel shaders

segment.source: We read data from the SimpleVertexShader.cso file and assign the data to the vertexShaderBytecode byte array.
segment.target: We read data from the SimpleVertexShader.cso file and assign the data to the vertexShaderBytecode byte array.

segment.source: We call ID3D11Device::CreateVertexShader with the byte array to create the vertex shader (ID3D11VertexShader).
segment.target: We call ID3D11Device::CreateVertexShader with the byte array to create the vertex shader (ID3D11VertexShader).

segment.source: We set the vertex depth value to 0.5 in the SimpleVertexShader.hlsl source to guarantee that our triangle is drawn.
segment.target: We set the vertex depth value to 0.5 in the SimpleVertexShader.hlsl source to guarantee that our triangle is drawn.

segment.source: We populate an array of D3D11\_INPUT\_ELEMENT\_DESC structures to describe the layout of the vertex shader code and then call ID3D11Device::CreateInputLayout to create the layout.
segment.target: We populate an array of D3D11\_INPUT\_ELEMENT\_DESC structures to describe the layout of the vertex shader code and then call ID3D11Device::CreateInputLayout to create the layout.

segment.source: The array has one layout element that defines the vertex position.
segment.target: The array has one layout element that defines the vertex position.

segment.source: We read data from the SimplePixelShader.cso file and assign the data to the pixelShaderBytecode byte array.
segment.target: We read data from the SimplePixelShader.cso file and assign the data to the pixelShaderBytecode byte array.

segment.source: We call ID3D11Device::CreatePixelShader with the byte array to create the pixel shader (ID3D11PixelShader).
segment.target: We call ID3D11Device::CreatePixelShader with the byte array to create the pixel shader (ID3D11PixelShader).

segment.source: We set the pixel value to (1,1,1,1) in the SimplePixelShader.hlsl source to make our triangle yellow.
segment.target: We set the pixel value to (1,1,1,1) in the SimplePixelShader.hlsl source to make our triangle yellow.

segment.source: You can change the color by changing this value.
segment.target: You can change the color by changing this value.

segment.source: We create vertex and index buffers that define a simple triangle.
segment.target: We create vertex and index buffers that define a simple triangle.

segment.source: To do this, we first define the triangle, next describe the vertex and index buffers (D3D11\_BUFFER\_DESC and D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA) using the triangle definition, and finally call ID3D11Device::CreateBuffer once for each buffer.
segment.target: To do this, we first define the triangle, next describe the vertex and index buffers (D3D11\_BUFFER\_DESC and D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA) using the triangle definition, and finally call ID3D11Device::CreateBuffer once for each buffer.

segment.source: We use the vertex and pixel shaders, the vertex shader layout, and the vertex and index buffers to draw a yellow triangle.
segment.target: We use the vertex and pixel shaders, the vertex shader layout, and the vertex and index buffers to draw a yellow triangle.

segment.source: 4. Drawing the triangle and presenting the rendered image
segment.target: 4. Drawing the triangle and presenting the rendered image

segment.source: We enter an endless loop to continually render and display the scene.
segment.target: We enter an endless loop to continually render and display the scene.

segment.source: We call ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargets to specify the render target as the output target.
segment.target: We call ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargets to specify the render target as the output target.

segment.source: We call ID3D11DeviceContext::ClearRenderTargetView with { 0.071f, 0.04f, 0.561f, 1.0f } to clear the render target to a solid blue color.
segment.target: We call ID3D11DeviceContext::ClearRenderTargetView with { 0.071f, 0.04f, 0.561f, 1.0f } to clear the render target to a solid blue color.

segment.source: In the endless loop, we draw a yellow triangle on the blue surface.
segment.target: In the endless loop, we draw a yellow triangle on the blue surface.

segment.source: To draw a yellow triangle
segment.target: To draw a yellow triangle

segment.source: First, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetInputLayout to describe how vertex buffer data is streamed into the input-assembler stage.
segment.target: First, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetInputLayout to describe how vertex buffer data is streamed into the input-assembler stage.

segment.source: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers and ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer to bind the vertex and index buffers to the input-assembler stage.
segment.target: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers and ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer to bind the vertex and index buffers to the input-assembler stage.

segment.source: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetPrimitiveTopology with the D3D11\_PRIMITIVE\_TOPOLOGY\_TRIANGLESTRIP value to specify for the input-assembler stage to interpret the vertex data as a triangle strip.
segment.target: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetPrimitiveTopology with the D3D11\_PRIMITIVE\_TOPOLOGY\_TRIANGLESTRIP value to specify for the input-assembler stage to interpret the vertex data as a triangle strip.

segment.source: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetShader to initialize the vertex shader stage with the vertex shader code and ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader to initialize the pixel shader stage with the pixel shader code.
segment.target: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetShader to initialize the vertex shader stage with the vertex shader code and ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader to initialize the pixel shader stage with the pixel shader code.

segment.source: Finally, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::DrawIndexed to draw the triangle and submit it to the rendering pipeline.
segment.target: Finally, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::DrawIndexed to draw the triangle and submit it to the rendering pipeline.

segment.source: We call IDXGISwapChain::Present to present the rendered image to the window.
segment.target: We call IDXGISwapChain::Present to present the rendered image to the window.

segment.source: Summary and next steps
segment.target: Summary and next steps

segment.source: We created and drew a yellow triangle by using vertex and pixel shaders.
segment.target: We created and drew a yellow triangle by using vertex and pixel shaders.

segment.source: Next, we create an orbiting 3D cube and apply lighting effects to it.
segment.target: Next, we create an orbiting 3D cube and apply lighting effects to it.

segment.source: Using depth and effects on primitives
segment.target: Using depth and effects on primitives
